reasoning: The critique targets a specific plank of the essay’s case for fussiness: in §3.2 (linear unbounded views), the claim that a Milky Way civilization is ~1/20B of best-feasible value, which helps generate the “fanaticism” pressure and supports the idea that mostly-great futures require near-total cosmic resource capture. If that arithmetic is badly misleading because distant matter has sharply rising shadow prices (energy/time/coordination/security), the scale-based part of the linear-view argument weakens. However, the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion is not primarily dependent on this; the essay also argues for narrow targets via (i) many independent moral dimensions (multiplicative fragility), (ii) fat-tailed value-efficiency even holding resources fixed, and (iii) bounded-view fussiness via sensitivity to bads. So centrality is moderate-low. Strength is moderate: it’s a plausible objection that ‘resources’ aren’t homogeneous and that effective accessible resources should be cost-weighted, but it’s under-argued (no quantitative thresholds, and Forethought could reply that ‘resources under control’ already implicitly nets out acquisition costs, or that even steeply rising costs still leave huge net gains on linear views). Relevance is fairly high because it engages Forethought’s space-expansion/industrial-explosion framing and the role of cosmic-scale capture in value calculations (a Tier 2 area with Tier 3-adjacent implications for space governance and “expansionism” urgency). Overall impact is limited but nontrivial.
title: The paper ignores rising costs of distant resource capture
